TextJPN: 昭和６０年　盛夏
TextENG: Midsummer, 1985

TextJPN: 時間の読みを間違え、早く来すぎてしまった。
TextENG: I had misread the time, and ended up arriving too early.

TextJPN: バタバタバタタ…と、時間表がめくれて行く。
TextENG: The schedule board flipped with a series of clacks.

TextJPN: 私の乗る札幌行きの便の出発は、まだまだ先だ。
TextENG: My flight to Sapporo was still a bit later on.

TextJPN: 搭乗手続き開始までにだって、まだ１時間はたっぷりあるようだった。
TextENG: I still had over an hour before boarding.

TextJPN: …なら、その辺のベンチで目を瞑るのもいいか。
TextENG: ...Well, I might as well close my eyes for a bit on that bench over there, then.

TextJPN: 勤務明けからそのまま来たので、疲れのせいか少し眠い。
TextENG: I came here directly from work, so maybe the fatigue from that was making me sleepy.

TextJPN: 適当なベンチが見つけられたので、荷物を隣の席に下ろし、深々と腰掛けた。
TextENG: Finding a suitable bench, I put my luggage on the seat next to me and settled down.

TextJPN: …娘の美雪は、すぐそばの売店に置かれたお土産や玩具を物珍しそうに眺め見ている。
TextENG: ...My daughter Miyuki looked at the souvenirs and toys in the nearby store with a curious look.

TextJPN: 先ほど、何か欲しいのかと聞いてみたが、いらないとの返答だった。どうやら、見ているだけで楽しいらしい。
TextENG: I asked her if she wanted something just now, but she replied that she didn't need anything. Apparently, it's fun to just look around.

TextJPN: 「…はぁあぁーーーーー……」
自然にこぼれるオヤジくさいため息。
TextENG: I sighed like an old man.

TextJPN: いつまでも若者のつもりだが、やはり自分も立派な中年なんだろう。
TextENG: I had hoped to stay young forever, but had become splendidly middle-aged.

TextJPN: …２０代も後半に入ると体力は衰える一方という噂は、どうやら嘘でもないようだ。
TextENG: ...Apparently the rumor that ``even people in the latter half of their twenties experience a decline in their physical strength`` wasn't a lie.

TextJPN: 最近は仕事に忙殺されるだけで、自分の時間というものを余り持たなかった。
TextENG: It had been mind-numbingly busy at work lately, so I rarely had any time to myself.

TextJPN: こんな風に、一人旅を楽しむなんてことは、学生時代以来かもしれない。
TextENG: This might have been the first time I'd been able to enjoy a journey alone like this since I was a student.

TextJPN: 一応念のため、内ポケットに差し込んでいた航空チケットを確かめる。
TextENG: Just to be sure, I checked my airplane ticket that I had inserted into my inner pocket.

TextJPN: …旅行の目的は旧友との再会だ。
TextENG: ...The reason behind this trip was to meet with an old friend.

TextJPN: 旧友と呼んでいいかは怪しい。@k…悪友と呼ぶべきかもしれない。
TextENG: It was a bit strange to call him an old friend...@k in fact, it might be better to call him a bad one.

TextJPN: 彼は一昨年に退職を迎えた後、母の故郷である札幌に引越した。
TextENG: After retiring a couple of years ago, he moved to Sapporo, his mother's hometown.

TextJPN: その母もすぐに他界し、今は優雅に第二の人生を送っているという。
TextENG: His mother passed away soon after, and he was now peacefully enjoying his second lease on life.

TextJPN: 彼の名は、大石蔵人。
TextENG: His name was Kuraudo Ooishi.

TextJPN: とある県警にある興宮署の刑事課に勤めていた元刑事だ。
TextENG: He was a former detective from the Primary Investigation Unit at the station in Okinomiya.

TextJPN: 私と彼が直接縁があったのは、実のところ、わずか三日間に過ぎない。
TextENG: To be honest, the only direct contact we ever had didn't last more than three days.

TextJPN: その後も、年賀状等でずっと縁はあったが、再会したことはなかった。
TextENG: After that, we exchanged New Year's cards, but never met again.

TextJPN: だから、彼と再会するのは…７年ぶりになる。
TextENG: So, this would be the first time meeting him in... seven years.

TextJPN: 私と彼が出会ったのは、つまり７年前。
TextENG: In other words, we met seven years ago.

TextJPN: 昭和５３年のこと。
あの当時のことで、…どうしても大石氏に聞きたいこと、話したいことがあるのだ。
TextENG: There was something I just had to ask--to talk to him about concerning that time.

TextJPN: それについて説明するには、…あの昭和５３年の事件を回想しなくてはならない。
TextENG: To explain that... it was impossible not to recall the incident that happened back then.

TextJPN: …何から何までが闇で決められ、闇に葬られた、あの誘拐事件。
TextENG: ...That kidnapping, the details and resolution of which were resigned to darkness.

TextJPN: そして、………ひとりの不思議な少女のことも思い出さなくてはならない。
TextENG: Also... it was impossible not to recall a certain mysterious girl.

TextJPN: 私の名は、@bあかさか.@<赤坂@>@bまもる.@<衛@>。
TextENG: My name is Mamoru Akasaka.

TextJPN: あれは、…まだ６月なのに妙に暑い年のことだった…。
TextENG: It was a year that had been strangely hot even though it was only June...

TextJPN: 昭和５３年　初夏
TextENG: Early Summer, 1978

TextJPN: 「「先生ぇ～、さよ～～ならッ！！」」
TextENG: ``````Goodbye, teacher!!``````

TextJPN: 「ハイ、さようなら。@k@vS05/00/teach00002.車に気を付けるんですよ。@k@vS05/00/teach00003.お友達の家に寄り道なんかしないように。@k@vS05/00/teach00004.明日の教科書の準備は必ず寝る前にしておくんですよ」
TextENG: ``Okay, bye.@k@vS05/00/teach00002. Watch out for cars.@k@vS05/00/teach00003. And don't drop in at a friend's house along the way.@k@vS05/00/teach00004. Make sure you get your textbooks in order for tomorrow before you go to bed.``

TextJPN: がたがたがたがた！！
TextENG: Clatter clatter clatter!

TextJPN: 児童たちが廊下へ飛び出していく賑やかな音。
TextENG: The lively sounds of children running towards the hallway.

TextJPN: 「でさ～～～、つってんだぜぇ？！」
TextENG: ``Hey now, didn't I tell you before!?``

TextJPN: 「そんなの俺、持ってるもんよー！！@k@vS05/00/toshi00002.　いらねぇよーッ！！」
TextENG: ``I already have one of those!!@k@vS05/00/toshi00002. I don't need any more!!``

TextJPN: 児童独特の甲高い声。
TextENG: The unique high-pitched voice of youth.

TextJPN: 賑やかに鳴くセミの声も、子供たちにはまったく届かないようだった。
TextENG: The energetic shrill of the cicadas went completely unheard by their ears.

TextJPN: 住宅地のあちこちの交差点で、仲良しグループで下校していた子供たちが、ひとり、ひとりと別れていく。
TextENG: Children, returning home from school, split off one-by-one from their groups of friends as they went through intersections in the residential area.

TextJPN: 昇降口を出た時には何人ものグループでも、家が近付けばその人数はどんどん減っていく。
TextENG: Even though there were several of them in a group as they left the school, as they got closer to their homes, their numbers dwindled.

TextJPN: …だから、下校する仲間の人数が少なくなるのは、それだけ家が近付いたという証拠。
TextENG: ...That's why the fewer friends you were walking home with acted as an indicator that you were that much closer to your destination.

TextJPN: 「じゃあなー！！@k@vS05/00/boyA00003.　あばよー！」
TextENG: ``Later!!@k@vS05/00/boyA00003. See ya!``

TextJPN: 「うん、また明日ねー」
TextENG: ``Yeah, see you tomorrow.``

TextJPN: 最後の友人とも別れる。
TextENG: He finally parted ways with his last friend.

TextJPN: …路地を曲がったところにワゴン車が止まっていた。
TextENG: ...A van was parked at a bend in the road.

TextJPN: 窓が開いていて、カーラジオの音が外に漏れ出している。@k…ニュースか何かのようだった。
TextENG: The window was open, the sound of the radio leaking outside.@k ...It must have been the news or something.

TextJPN: 「…たため、道路交通法違反、公務執行妨害で３名を逮捕しました」
TextENG: ``...for that reason, the three of them were arrested for traffic violations and obstruction of justice.

TextJPN: 「一連の雛見沢ダム建設反対を巡る運動は、先月の機動隊との流血事件を境に過激化の一途を辿っており、@k@vS05/00/radio00003.警察では過激な活動家による次の事件を警戒しています」
TextENG: Due to the protests against the Hinamizawa Dam Project resulting in bloodshed when clashing with riot police last month, things have only become more violent.@k@vS05/00/radio00003. The police are therefore taking precautions against radical activists causing yet another incident.

TextJPN: 「先週も、建設省庁舎前での犬飼建設大臣への直訴事件があったばかりで…、」
TextENG: Last week, there was also a direct confrontation with Minister Inukai on the steps of the Ministry of Construction...``

TextJPN: 犬飼建設大臣という名に、少年はぴくりと耳を動かした。
TextENG: The boy's ears perked up at the mention of the name ``Inukai``.

TextJPN: その時、ラジオの音が漏れていた車の窓から、ひょっこりと男が顔を出した。
TextENG: At that moment, a man's face peeked out suddenly from the window of the van.

TextJPN: 車の扉を開けるときの仕草が、前後から人や車が来てないか、確かめるための仕草とは少し異なった。
TextENG: His behavior was a little different than that of a man looking around to see if there was any incoming traffic before he opened the door of his vehicle.

TextJPN: …面識のない男と突然、目が合い、少年は少し狼狽する…。
TextENG: ...His eyes meeting suddenly with the unfamiliar man, the boy panicked slightly...

TextJPN: 「…鶯、ＯＫ」
TextENG: ``...Nightingale, okay.``

TextJPN: 「雲雀、ＯＫ。@k@vS05/00/hibari00002.前後２ブロック確保した。@k@vS05/00/hibari00003.…いいぞ…！」
TextENG: ``Skylark, okay.@k@vS05/00/hibari00002. They've secured the two blocks around us.@k@vS05/00/hibari00003. ...We're good to go!``

TextJPN: 助手席の男が小さく耳打ちする。
TextENG: The man in the passenger seat whispered quietly.

TextJPN: 男は頷くと扉を開け、…少年の前に立ちはだかった。
TextENG: Nodding in acknowledgement, the man opened the door... and stood before the boy.

TextJPN: 「……キミ、…犬飼寿樹くん？」
TextENG: ``...You. ...Are you Toshiki Inukai-kun?``

TextJPN: 男はそう尋ねながら少年の名札を覗き込んだ。
TextENG: While asking that, the man peered at the boy's nametag.

TextJPN: …『いぬかいとしき』、名札には平仮名でそう書かれていた…。
TextENG: ...``Toshiki Inukai``... the name was written plainly there...

TextJPN: 電話の呼び出し音が三度目になった。
TextENG: The phone rang for a third time.

TextJPN: 手を伸ばせば、すぐに受話器は取れる。
TextENG: If he reached out, he could easily pick up the receiver.

TextJPN: …だが、一度目の呼び出し音が鳴り止みもしない内に受話器を取ると、相手に安っぽくみられるのではないかと彼は気にしていた。
TextENG: ...However, he was concerned that if he picked it up before it had even finished ringing once, whoever was on the other end of the line would think him a fairly cheap person.

TextJPN: だから、彼は常に呼び出し音が三度鳴るまでは受話器を取ろうとしなかった。
TextENG: That's why he normally never picked up the phone until the third ring.

TextJPN: 自分でもつまらない癖だなとは思っている。
TextENG: Even he thought it was a worthless habit.

TextJPN: …だが、三度待たせる程度では、そんなに意味がないのではないか、五度くらいは待たせてもいいんじゃないか、なんて自分がいるのもまた事実だ。
TextENG: ...However, his thinking that ``there isn't much meaning in waiting for just three rings, wouldn't waiting for five be all right?`` was very much a reality.

TextJPN: そんな下らないことを頭に満たしながら、彼は三度目の呼び出し音が鳴り終わった余韻を噛み締めながら受話器を取った…。
TextENG: His mind filled with such trifling thoughts, he picked up the phone after the third ring had finished, its reverb dampened by his action...

TextJPN: たまに交換機の不調で、通話がうまくつながらない時があることを彼は知っていた。
TextENG: He knew that sometimes due to a malfunction at the switchboard, calls didn't connect well.

TextJPN: そういう時はさっさと電話を切り、もう一度先方に掛け直させればいい。
TextENG: At those times, it was best to hang up and let the person on the other end call again.

TextJPN: …そう思い、受話器を置こうとした時。@k…彼はこの電話が確かに繋がっていて、受話器の向こうには、声を潜めた何者かが確かに存在する気配を感じ取る…。
TextENG: ...Thinking that, the moment he began to hang up the phone...@k ...He sensed that he was definitely connected after all. He felt the presence of the person on the other end of the line, keeping silent...

TextJPN: こちらの問い掛けが聞こえていないはずはない。@k…これは一体どうしたことだ？
TextENG: There was no way they didn't hear his question.@k ...What was the meaning of this?

TextJPN: 無言電話というものを、彼が知らなかったわけはない。
TextENG: It wasn't like he didn't know that people could use silent calls to harass others.

TextJPN: だが彼はそんな電話を今日まで一度も取ったことはなかった。
TextENG: However, he'd never received a call like that until today.

TextJPN: …それが、単に幸運なことだったにせよ、…この電話にそんなものがつながるなんてこと自体が信じられなかった。
TextENG: ...Maybe he was just lucky before, but he didn't believe that he would receive such a call on this phone.

TextJPN: この電話には直通はない。
TextENG: There were no direct calls to or from this line.

TextJPN: 受話も送話も全てオペレーターを通す。
TextENG: Everything had to go through an operator.

TextJPN: だから、身元の確認できない人間からの電話が取り次がれることは絶対にない。
TextENG: Therefore, there was absolutely no way the call would be connected unless it was verified there was somebody else on the other end of the line.

TextJPN: だからこそ彼は、この理解できない無言電話にどう対応していいかわからず、困惑をしかけていた…。
TextENG: That's why he didn't understand how to deal with this silent call, and instead settled into confusion...

TextJPN: 「……あんた、誰だか知らないが、用がないなら切るよ。@k@vS05/00/inuk00009.また掛けなおして下さい」
TextENG: ``...I don't know who you are, but if you have nothing to say I'm going to hang up.@k@vS05/00/inuk00009. Please call again some other time.``

TextJPN: それを捨て台詞に、受話器をガチャンと叩きつけようとした。
TextENG: Intending that to be a parting line, he made to slam down the receiver.

TextJPN: …そこで、相手は初めて、言葉を口にする。
TextENG: ...It was at that moment, the person on the other end spoke for the first time.

TextJPN: 「………アナタガ名乗ッテクレナイカラ困ッテンデスヨ。@k@vS05/14/104700002.アンタガ犬飼大臣ジャナイナラ、サッサト電話ヲ切ッテ下サイ」
TextENG: ``...You didn't say who you were, so I was anxious.@k@vS05/14/104700002. If you're not Minister Inukai, please hang up right away.``

TextJPN: 受話器の向こうから聞こえた、奇妙極まりない妙な声に驚かずにはいられなかった。
TextENG: He couldn't help but be surprised by the extremely strange voice on the other end of the line.

TextJPN: …こんな変なかすれたような、…金属的な声で喋れる人間がいるのか？
TextENG: ...Was there a human alive who could speak with this hoarse and metallic voice?

TextJPN: …いやいや、…これは…どこかで聞いたことのある声だ。
TextENG: ... No. ...This was... a voice he had heard somewhere before.

TextJPN: そう、よく低俗なドキュメンタリー番組で、身元を隠して告白する時に、音声は変えてお送りいたしております…なんて声になるじゃないか。
TextENG: That was the kind of voice that was on those lowbrow documentaries, that they'd use when they wanted to hide the identity of a speaker, wasn't it?

TextJPN: …この受話器の向こうから聞こえてくる声は、まさにそんな感じだった。
TextENG: ...The voice he was hearing over the line was exactly like that.

TextJPN: 「……あんた、…誰」
TextENG: ``... Who... are you?``

TextJPN: 「………ダカラ、ソレハコッチガ聞イテルンデスヨ。@k@vS05/14/104700004.アンタ、犬飼大臣ジャナイノ？」
TextENG: ``....As I said, that's what I want to ask.@k@vS05/14/104700004. Are you Minister Inukai?``

TextJPN: 彼は、…犬飼は返事に躊躇した。
TextENG: He -- Inukai -- hesitated to answer.

TextJPN: この不審な電話の真意が読み取れず、…漠然とした薄気味悪さすら感じる。
TextENG: Unable to discern the intent of this suspicious phone call, he had a vague feeling that something was off.

TextJPN: 受話器を切り、オペレーターにこの電話の主は何者か聞こうとも思った。
TextENG: He thought about hanging up the phone and asking the operator who initiated the call.

TextJPN: …だが、彼はそういう気持ちを理性で抑え、とりあえず名乗り、話を聞くことを選ぶ。
TextENG: ...However, he forced himself to restrain that urge, and for the time being, chose to state his name and listen.

TextJPN: 「…そうです。@k@vS05/00/inuk00012.犬飼です。@k@vS05/00/inuk00013.……名乗りましたよ、だからあんたも名乗ってくださいよ」
TextENG: ``...That's right.@k@vS05/00/inuk00012. This is Inukai.@k@vS05/00/inuk00013. ...I said my name, now you say yours.``

TextJPN: 「………私ノ名前ナンテ、ドウデモイインデス。@k@vS05/14/104700006.マズ、アナタガドウイウ立場ニ置カレテイルカ、ソレヲ認識スルトコロカラ始メマショウ」
TextENG: ``...My name doesn't matter.@k@vS05/14/104700006. First of all, let's begin by thinking about the situation you're in right now.

TextJPN: 「…アナタハ今、自分ノ席デ電話ヲシテイマスネ？@k@vS05/14/104700008.　デハ、アナタノ席ノ右側ノ一番下ノ引キ出シヲ開ケテミテクダサイ」
TextENG: ...Right now, you're sitting in your chair talking on the phone, yes?@k@vS05/14/104700008. Then, why don't you try opening the lower drawer to your right.``

TextJPN: 大臣席の右側の一番下の引き出し。
TextENG: The lowest drawer to the right of the minister's chair.

TextJPN: …それは鍵の掛かった引き出しで、金庫にしまうほどでないにしても、それなりに重要なものをしまう位置付けの引き出しだった。
TextENG: ...There was a lock on it. Not enough to function as a safe, but nevertheless it was a drawer that contained some valuable things.

TextJPN: だから犬飼は、その引き出しの中にある何かの重要な情報を欲しがっているんだろうな、と思った。
TextENG: That's why Inukai thought that the person wanted some of the important information contained within that drawer.

TextJPN: 「…すまんが、開けるつもりはないよ。@k@vS05/00/inuk00015.自分の名前も名乗れんヤツの言いなりになる謂れはない」
TextENG: ``...Sorry, but I don't have any intention of opening that.@k@vS05/00/inuk00015. I have no reason to follow orders from somebody who won't even give me his name.``

TextJPN: 「引キ出シヲ開ケテクレナイナラ、コノ電話ヲ切リマス。@k@vS05/14/104700010.…キット、後悔スルコトニナリマスヨ？@k@vS05/14/104700011.　マズハ引キ出シヲ開ケテカラ考エテモイインジャナイデスカ？」
TextENG: ``If you don't open that drawer, I'll hang up the phone.@k@vS05/14/104700010. ...You will most likely end up regretting that.@k@vS05/14/104700011. Why don't you think about opening that drawer first?``

TextJPN: 犬飼はこの不審な相手の言いなりになるのは、とにかく不快だった。
TextENG: Inukai didn't like following orders from this suspicious person one bit.

TextJPN: …だが、後悔することになるという言葉が気にかかり、引き出しを開けてみることにする。
TextENG: ...However, he was concerned about what the man said about ``regretting it,`` so he decided to open the drawer.

TextJPN: 彼は自分の財布にしまっている小さなカギを取り出し、それで引き出しのカギを開けた。
TextENG: He took the small key he kept stowed in his wallet, and unlocked the drawer.

TextJPN: …引き出しを開ける直前、手が止まる。
TextENG: ...His hand stopped right before he opened it.

TextJPN: 中に爆弾でも入っていて…、引き出しを開けることによって爆発するのでは…？
TextENG: What if there was a bomb inside... and it would explode if the drawer was opened...?

TextJPN: そんな妄想に取り憑かれたからだ。
TextENG: That delusion took hold of him.

TextJPN: それでも意を決し、…開く。
TextENG: He quelled that instinct, and opened it.

TextJPN: 「…開ケテクレマシタカ？@k@vS05/14/104700013.　ソコニアル物ガ何カ、ワカリマスヨネ？」
TextENG: ``...Did you do it?@k@vS05/14/104700013. The thing that's in there, do you know what it is?``

TextJPN: 「…………これは……どういうことだ？！@k@vS05/00/inuk00017.　おいッ！！」
TextENG: ``...This is... What is the meaning of this!?@k@vS05/00/inuk00017. Hey!!``

TextJPN: 「ドウイウコトカ、説明スル必要ナンカ、ナイデスヨネ。@k@vS05/14/104700015.時間ヲ差シ上ゲマスノデ、少シオ考エ下サイ。@k@vS05/14/104700016.マタ後ホド、コチラカラ連絡イタシマス。@k@vS05/14/104700017.ソレデハ失礼……」
TextENG: ``I don't think there's any need for me to explain, is there?@k@vS05/14/104700015. I'll give you some time, so please think about it a little.@k@vS05/14/104700016. I'll contact you again later.@k@vS05/14/104700017. Now then, pardon me...``
``Hey!@k@vS05/00/inuk00019. Wait!!@k@vS05/00/inuk00020. Hello!?@k@vS05/00/inuk00021. HELLO!?!?``

TextJPN: すでに電話は切れている。
TextENG: The call had already ended.

TextJPN: いくら怒鳴っても意味はない。
TextENG: That would not change no matter how much he yelled at it.

TextJPN: …にも拘らず、犬飼はしばらくの間、それを思いだせず、受話器に怒鳴り続けていた。
TextENG: ...Even still, Inukai, without realizing that, continued yelling into the receiver for a while.

TextJPN: …開かれたままの引き出し。
TextENG: ...The drawer was still open.

TextJPN: …ぎっしり詰まったたくさんのフォルダの上にちょこんと、それは乗せられていた。
TextENG: ...On top of the folders crammed into the drawer, it lay there.

TextJPN: 『いぬかいとしき』
TextENG: ``Toshiki Inukai``

TextJPN: 平仮名で書かれた小学生の名札が、…ちょこんと。
TextENG: Written in plain lettering on a grade-schooler's nametag... just lying there.

TextJPN: 場違いな場所に、まるで畏縮するかのように、鎮座していた…。
TextENG: Enshrined there, completely out of place, as if it were cowering...

TextJPN: ……覚えてるかい、雪絵。@kこの写真。
TextENG: ...Do you remember, Yukie?@k This picture.

TextJPN: 君に私が、初めてプロポーズをした場所だよ。
TextENG: This is where I first proposed to you.

TextJPN: …君が頷き返してくれるまでのわずかな時間が、@k私にとって、@kどれほど張り詰めていて…永遠とも思える時間だったか、@k君にはわからないだろうね。
TextENG: ...That brief moment before you nodded back,@k you probably wouldn't know just how much@k it seemed like@k an eternity to me.

TextJPN: えぇ。@k私にはその程度の時間で永遠だなんて思われたら、@rたまりません…。
TextENG: Yes.@k I would have never thought that amount of time could feel like an eternity.

TextJPN: あなたが求婚の言葉を口にして下さるまでに、@r私が待ち焦がれた時間に比べれば、とてもとても…。
TextENG: Compared to how long I had to wait for you to propose to me, it was...

TextJPN: はははははは…。
TextENG: Hahahahahaha...

TextJPN: あなたと出会ってから今日まで。
TextENG: From the moment I met you until today...

TextJPN: …私が生まれてから過ごしてきた時間と比べれば、@rそれはわずかな時間かもしれないけれども…。
TextENG: ...Compared to the time I've spent since I was born, it might only be a brief period, but...

TextJPN: それはきっと、永遠と呼べるくらいに尊くて美しい、@r…色あせない日々。
TextENG: They were definitely precious, beautiful days that deserved to be called an eternity.

TextJPN: …そんな時間はこれからも続く。
TextENG: ...That time continues even now.

TextJPN: …これからもね。
TextENG: ...From now on.

TextJPN: 生まれる子は…男の子かしら。@k女の子かしら。
TextENG: I wonder if it'll be a boy...@k or maybe a girl?

TextJPN: …どちらでもいいよ。
TextENG: ...Either one is fine.

TextJPN: 男でも女でも、…私たちが確かに愛し合った証の、生命なんだから。
TextENG: Boy or girl... either way it's living proof that we love each other.

TextJPN: 男の子だったら、あなたの名前の一字『衛』を名前に加える。
TextENG: If it's a boy, we'll name it after you: ``Mamoru.``

TextJPN: 女の子だったら、私の名前の一字『雪』を加える…。
TextENG: If it's a girl, we'll put the ``Yuki`` from my name in hers...

TextJPN: 何て名前にするのか考えるのが楽しくて、…結局今日まで決まらなかったね。
TextENG: Thinking about names is so fun that in the end we still haven't decided yet.

TextJPN: まだ迷える時間はありますよ。@k@r…そんなに長い時間ではないけれど。
TextENG: There's still time to puzzle over it.@k ...Not that long of a time, actually.

TextJPN: ………実は雪絵。@k…今日は少し、謝ることがある。
TextENG: ....You see, Yukie.@k ...There's something I have to apologize for today.

TextJPN: …お仕事のことですね。
TextENG: ...It's about your job.

TextJPN: ……………すまない。
TextENG: ...Sorry.

TextJPN: …どうもややこしい仕事が入るみたいだ。@k…下手をすると、……出産日に、…駆けつけられないかもしれない。
TextENG: ...It looks like an annoying bit of work has come up.@k ...In the worst case, ...I might not be able to be there for the delivery.

TextJPN: いいんですよ。
TextENG: It's fine.

TextJPN: あなたはとても大切な仕事をしています。
TextENG: You have a very important job.

TextJPN: それは私たちの生活を守るために重要なもの。
TextENG: What you do protects the way we live.

TextJPN: ……君と比べたら、大したことじゃない。
TextENG: ....Compared to you, it's nothing.

TextJPN: どうか、行ってらして下さい。
TextENG: Please, go ahead.

TextJPN: お帰りを、生まれる子と二人で待っています。
TextENG: When you return, I'll be waiting here with our child.

TextJPN: ありがとう。@k…そして、…すまない。
TextENG: Thank you.@k ...Also, I'm sorry.

TextJPN: …どうか謝らないで下さい。
TextENG: ...Please don't apologize.

TextJPN: もしも罪の意識を感じられるなら…、いつかその分の、@r罪滅ぼしをしてくだされば結構ですから。
TextENG: If you feel guilty about it... then you can just atone.

TextJPN: …あんな罪滅ぼしを何度もしてたら、お金がいくらあっても足りないよ。
TextENG: If I atone that much, no matter how much money I have, it won't be enough.

TextJPN: くすくす…。@k冗談です。
TextENG: Hee hee.@k It's a joke.

TextJPN: …さ、…行ってらしてくださいな…。
TextENG: ...Now ...Go on..

TextJPN: 部屋を出たところで、初老の男と鉢合せした。
TextENG: As I left the room, I bumped into an elderly man.

TextJPN: …雪絵の父。@k…私にとっての、義父だった。
TextENG: ...It was Yukie's father.@k ...In other words, my father-in-law.

TextJPN: 「…お義父さん」
TextENG: ``...Father.``

TextJPN: 「邪魔する気はなかったからな。@k@vS05/00/Lfar00002.廊下で待たせてもらったよ」
TextENG: ``I didn't want to intrude.@k@vS05/00/Lfar00002. So I waited in the hall.``

TextJPN: 「聞き耳を立てるつもりはなかったが、聞こえてしまった。@k@vS05/00/Lfar00004.…行き給え。@k@vS05/00/Lfar00005.雪絵はああいう娘だ。@k@vS05/00/Lfar00006.…何があっても、自分が君の枷になることを望むまい」
TextENG: ``I didn't mean to eavesdrop, but I heard.@k@vS05/00/Lfar00004. ...Go.@k@vS05/00/Lfar00005. Yukie is that kind of girl.@k@vS05/00/Lfar00006. ...No matter what happens, she doesn't want to hold you back.``

TextJPN: 「……私は、…これまで雪絵に様々な犠牲を強いてきました。@k@vS05/13/101300005.…出産という人生の節目にまで、…彼女に犠牲を強いることを…恥じます」
TextENG: ``...I've... forced Yukie to give up on so many things.@k@vS05/13/101300005. To put her through this during childbirth, such an important time in her life... I'm ashamed.``

TextJPN: 「…君が本当にそう思うなら、…仕事が終わったら、雪絵のために時間を割きなさい。@k@vS05/00/Lfar00008.…君が仕事を投げ出して付き添ってくれるよりも、そうした方がきっと雪絵も喜ぶだろう」
TextENG: ``...If you really feel that way, ...When you're done with your work, make some time for Yukie.@k@vS05/00/Lfar00008. ...She'll be happier with that than you passing your work off on someone else.``

TextJPN: 「……ありがとうございます」
TextENG: ``...Thank you.``

TextJPN: 「君が、とても大切な仕事をしていることは私もよく知っている。@k@vS05/00/Lfar00010.自分の仕事を誇りに思いなさい。@k@vS05/00/Lfar00011.雪絵は、君が見事難題を解決して凱旋するのを楽しみにしている…」
TextENG: ``I know full well you do important work.@k@vS05/00/Lfar00010. Be proud in what you do.@k@vS05/00/Lfar00011. Yukie is looking forward to your triumphant return...``

TextJPN: 「…はい」
表に待たせてあったタクシーに飛び乗る。
TextENG: I jumped into the taxi that was waiting outside.

TextJPN: ここへやって来た時と比べると、料金メーターの数字は大きく増えていた。
TextENG: Compared to the time when I first got here, the numbers on the fare meter had grown considerably.

TextJPN: …私と雪絵にとってのささやかな時間は、どうも客観的にはささやかとは言えないらしい。
TextENG: ...It seemed the modest time Yukie and I had spent together wasn't so modest from an objective point of view.

TextJPN: 「待たせてすみません。@k@vS05/13/101300009.やって下さい」
TextENG: ``Sorry to keep you waiting.@k@vS05/13/101300009. Go ahead.``

TextJPN: 「…いえいえ。@k@vS05/00/dri00002.では参りますよ」
TextENG: ``...No worries.@k@vS05/00/dri00002. Well then, off we go.``

TextJPN: タクシーはガクンガクン、とギアを入れなおすと軽やかに加速し、妻の病院をあっという間にビル群の向こうに埋もれさせてしまった。
TextENG: The taxi jerked as it changed gears to accelerate, soon burying the hospital my wife was in behind a throng of buildings.

TextJPN: …厄介なヤマとなれば、…しばらく戻ることはできないだろう。
TextENG: ...If it was to end up as a really troublesome ordeal... I probably wouldn't be returning for quite some time.

TextJPN: 新米で、しかも非番の私を呼び戻すということは…、恐らく室長は全職員を招集したに違いない。
TextENG: To call a rookie like me, and on top of that, one who's off duty... It seemed that the section chief was calling for all hands on deck.

TextJPN: ベテランの上級職員が緊急招集されることは、時にあることだが。
TextENG: The veteran upper brass gathering on an emergency basis happened occasionally...

TextJPN: …全職員を招集するような事態は…初めて経験する。
TextENG: This was the first time, though, that I experienced everybody gathering together like this.

TextJPN: 何が起こるにせよ、…初めて経験する事態なのは間違いなかった。
TextENG: Whatever was happening, there was no doubt it was going to be something novel.

TextJPN: ……妻の出産を控えるこの時期に。@k…悪態をつけばキリがない。
TextENG: ...Right when my wife was ready to give birth.@k ...If I wanted to spend the time to curse my misfortunes, I'd be here all day.

TextJPN: いつもなら心を晴れ晴れとさせる青いいちょう並木も、今日は精彩を欠いて見えた…。
TextENG: Even the verdant gingko trees lining the street that always brightened my mood seemed to lack some of their usual lustre...

TextJPN: やがて…庁舎が見えてきた。
TextENG: Eventually, the government office came into view.

TextJPN: 軽く息を止め、…全身に緊張感を取り戻す。
TextENG: Briefly holding my breath... I let the feelings of tension course through my body once again.

TextJPN: ………自分がいかに大切で重要で、…困難な仕事をしているかを思い出せ。
TextENG: ...I had to remember the work I was doing was important, necessary... and difficult.

TextJPN: 心を落ち着け、…精神を鋭利に。
TextENG: I composed myself and sharpened my wit.

TextJPN: ……よし。
TextENG: ...Ready.

TextJPN: タクシーは庁舎の前で止まった。
TextENG: The taxi stopped in front of the building.

TextJPN: 東京　霞ヶ関　警視庁公安部
TextENG: Kasumigaseki, Tokyo@r@rMetropolitan Police Department@rPublic Safety Division

TextJPN: 「室長、全員揃いました。@k@vS05/00/VV_kano_10000a.赤坂くん、ブラインド下ろしてくれる？」
TextENG: ``Chief, everyone's here.@k@vS05/00/VV_kano_10000a. Akasaka-kun, could you close the blinds?``

TextJPN: ブラインドを下ろすのはプロジェクターを使用する時と、不穏な内容が含まれる話がされる時だ。
TextENG: The blinds were usually closed when they needed to use the projector, or if the discussion was going to contain some particularly disturbing content.

TextJPN: ブラインドが、しゃーっという小気味よい音を立てながら、室内の採光を奪っていく。
TextENG: The blinds closed with a satisfying sound, darkening the interior of the room.

TextJPN: …やがて室内は、爽やかな朝の空気を完全に失い、無機質な蛍光灯の灯だけになった。
TextENG: ...Immediately, the inside of the room was completely drained of the pleasant morning atmosphere, leaving behind only the cold illumination of the fluorescent lighting.

TextJPN: 全員の顔が揃っていることを主任が確認し、室長にもう一度頷く。
TextENG: After the supervisor ensured that everyone was present, he nodded to the section chief once again.

TextJPN: …室長は張りつめた空気の中、厳かに立ち上がり、切り出した。
TextENG: ...With everybody on the edge of their seats, the chief stood up solemnly, and began to give his report.

TextJPN: 「推定４８時間前、建設大臣の孫にあたる、建設省幹部の子息が誘拐された模様です。@k@vS05/00/104200003.建設大臣は事態を穏便に済ませるため、警察へ通報せず、要求に応じるものと思われます」
TextENG: ``Approximately 48 hours ago, the Minister of Construction's grandson, who is also the son of one of his staff leaders, is believed to have been kidnapped.@k@vS05/00/104200003. It is believed the Minister, in an effort to resolve matters amicably, chose not to report the situation to the police and plans to cede to the demands imposed upon him.``

TextJPN: 今から推定４８時間前、建設大臣の孫である、建設省幹部の子息が誘拐されたらしい。
TextENG: It seemed that approximately 48 hours earlier, the Minister of Construction's grandson, who was also the son of one of his senior staff members, was kidnapped.

TextJPN: されたらしい、という言い方になるのは、事件の当事者がそれを認めていないからだ。
TextENG: The reason why it was phrased that way was because the person in question didn't admit it had happened.

TextJPN: 「大臣宅の通話を監視した結果、都外からと思われる不審な電話が数件確認されました」
TextENG: ``Based on the results of surveillance conducted on the Minister's residence, multiple suspicious phone calls from what is believed to be outside the city took place.

TextJPN: 「誘拐された子どもは病気療養中となっているが、通院の形跡はなく、周辺での目撃例もなく。@k@vS05/00/104200006.その他いくつかの理由から、事件発生は間違いないものと断定しました」
TextENG: The abducted child is said to be under treatment for some illness, but there's no trace of any hospital records or witnesses to such effect.@k@vS05/00/104200006. Due to that and various other reasons, we believe without a doubt that a kidnapping has occurred.``

TextJPN: …ここでは、どういう経緯でこの事件が明るみに出たのかは割愛される。
TextENG: ...Here, they omitted the details that brought this incident to light.

TextJPN: ちょっと考えれば、事件発覚以前の段階、@kつまり日常的に大臣宅の通話監視（我々は盗聴という言葉は使わない）をしていたことが想像できるだろう。
TextENG: If you think about it a bit, that meant that before this incident happened,@k the Minister's residence had been under surveillance already (I won't use the words ``spied upon``).

TextJPN: もちろん、裁判所の許可はないし、国民にも説明はとても難しい…。
TextENG: Of course, there wouldn't have been court approval for this, and it would have been very hard to explain to ordinary citizens...

TextJPN: だが今回のように、未然に凶悪な事件を嗅ぎ付けるにはとても有効な手段なのだ…。
TextENG: However, it was quite an effective method to catch wind of incidents like this before they got worse.

TextJPN: 事件が起こる前に対処することもまた、我々公安部の仕事なのを理解してほしい。
TextENG: I'd like for you to understand that dealing with these cases before they become a problem is the job of the Public Safety Division.

TextJPN: 「なぜ警察に通報せず要求を鵜呑みに？」
TextENG: ``Why is he just following their demands instead of reporting this to the police?``

TextJPN: 「大臣たる者が警察を信用できないってんだから、世も末だね」
TextENG: ``The fact that a Minister can't even trust the police, what is the world coming to?``

TextJPN: 「犯人グループは誘拐初期に、自分たちが大臣の生活をかなり高度に監視していることを警告し、その証拠を示した様子です。@k@vS05/00/104200008.大臣が屈伏し、警察への通報も思い止まるほどの何かですね」
TextENG: ``It seems the group of perpetrators demonstrated that they have quite a high level of surveillance on the Minister themselves when they conducted the kidnappings.@k@vS05/00/104200008. Enough to give the Minister pause before calling the police.``

TextJPN: 「警察へ通報してもすぐにわかるぞ、って？」
TextENG: ``'We'll find out right away if you call the cops,' more or less?``

TextJPN: 「大臣の近辺に内通者がいる可能性、か」
TextENG: ``So it's possible that there's a mole close to the Minister.``

TextJPN: この手の事件に経験があるらしい、上級職員の何人かがため息を漏らす…。
TextENG: Several of the higher ranking members who seemed to have experience with this kind of thing let out deep sighs...

TextJPN: 「犯人グループの目的が、要求にあるのか、事件そのものにあるのかは不明ですが、@k@vS05/00/104200010.いずれにせよ、国益を脅かす事態に発展する可能性が極めて高い」
TextENG: ``The goals of the perpetrators, their demands, as well as this entire incident are as of yet unclear,@k@vS05/00/104200010. but in any case, the possibility that this may grow to threaten national interest is extremely high.``

TextJPN: 要求を通すのが目的の、単なる営利目的の犯行ならまだ可愛い。
TextENG: If their goal was to simply have their demands met for monetary gain, that would have been nice.

TextJPN: …だが、大臣を揺さぶり何らかの政治的アクションを狙った犯行だとすると、背後関係は急に複雑になる。
TextENG: ...However, if this was some politically-motivated shake-up, things would get a lot more complicated.

TextJPN: 「被害者の協力がないということは、脅迫内容も要求も一切不明、ということか…」
TextENG: ``Since we're not receiving any cooperation from the victim, that means that we're not privy to any of the details of the threats or demands...``

TextJPN: 「本件は内通者の水準がかなり高いと思われるため、当室のみの極秘捜査とします。@k@vS05/00/104200012.また本件は本日より最優先事項となり、これまでの通常業務を一時凍結して対応します。@k@vS05/00/104200013.よろしいですね？！」
TextENG: ``Due to the fact we believe there may be a mole involved in this incident, this investigation is highly classified; only the people in this room are to know of this.@k@vS05/00/104200012. Furthermore, as this case is our utmost priority, we'll be placing a hold on everybody's normal duties.@k@vS05/00/104200013. Understood!?``

TextJPN: その後は主任が引き継ぎ、手際よく今後について説明していった。
TextENG: After that, the supervisor continued on, tactfully explaining our course of action.

TextJPN: 事件が公になった場合、大臣の政治生命に危険が及ぶ可能性がある。
TextENG: If this incident were to become public, it was possible that the Minister's political life would be over.

TextJPN: …その後のドミノ連鎖は割愛するが、最終的に内閣支持率低下、@k解散総選挙、@k共産勢力の拡大を許す結果となりかねない。
TextENG: ...I'll spare you the explanation of how the rest of the dominoes would fall, but in the end, support in the Diet would decline,@k followed by a no-confidence vote and a snap election,@k and it might even expand communist influences.

TextJPN: …デリケートな対応が求められるということだ。
TextENG: ...In other words, we wanted to handle this delicately.

TextJPN: 「川崎と佐伯は大臣宅、子供宅の通話を２４時間監視。@k@vS05/00/104200015.大臣の動向を探れ。@k@vS05/00/104200016.動きがある度に逐一報告せよ」
TextENG: ``Kawasaki and Saeki, monitor communications from the Minister and the child's residences 24/7.@k@vS05/00/104200015. Find out what the Minister is doing.@k@vS05/00/104200016. Report anything that happens.``

TextJPN: 「残る各職員は担当団体ごとに本件との関連を調査。@k@vS05/00/104200018.最近動きが不穏な特殊ラインは集中的にやれ！@k@vS05/00/104200019.　それから外国勢力も水を漏らすな！」
TextENG: ``The remaining members, investigate whatever is related to the case as assigned to your units.@k@vS05/00/104200018. Focus your line of investigation on recently active subversives.@k@vS05/00/104200019. Don't discount the possibility of foreign involvement, either!``

TextJPN: …穏便でない事態は一度か二度経験した。@kだが、こんなに慌ただしいのは初めてだった。
TextENG: I've experienced one or two... unamicable situations before.@k This, however, was the first time I've seen things get so hectic.

TextJPN: 私のような新米は抜きで、次々に高度な話が進んでいく。
TextENG: Several sophisticated conversations were progressing without the involvement of a rookie like me.

TextJPN: …仕事に臆すつもりはないが、初めての事態に困惑は隠せなかった。
TextENG: ...I didn't intend to be timid, but I couldn't hide my confusion at this unfamiliar situation.

TextJPN: 「…では、垣内に行ってくれ。@k@vS05/00/VV_kano_10002.で、赤坂くんは、」
TextENG: ``--and cover Kakiuchi.@k@vS05/00/VV_kano_10002. As for Akasaka-kun,``

TextJPN: 自分の名前を呼ばれ、ぼやけていた意識が戻る。
TextENG: I snapped back to alertness upon hearing my name called.

TextJPN: 「は、はい！」
TextENG: ``Y-Yes!``

TextJPN: 「赤坂くんは大臣に陳情してきた環境保護団体関連を調査してくれ。@k@vS05/00/VV_kano_10004.中でも、新聞でも騒ぎになってる雛見沢ダム建設反対の団体をよく調査すること」
TextENG: ``You investigate the environmental groups that have petitioned the minister.@k@vS05/00/VV_kano_10004. Among them, there's that group protesting the Hinamizawa Dam Project that made the papers. Make sure you investigate them thoroughly.

TextJPN: 「住民団体の仕業とは到底思えないが、全ての可能性を潰していかなくてはならない」
TextENG: I doubt this is the act of some citizen group, but we have to eliminate every possibility we can.``

TextJPN: 「わかりました。@k@vS05/13/101300012.雛見沢ダム反対、…か」
TextENG: ``Understood.@k@vS05/13/101300012. So those opposed to the Hinamizawa Dam...``

TextJPN: 「直接現地へ行った方がいいだろう。@k@vS05/00/VV_kano_10007.現地県警で情報を取れ。@k@vS05/00/VV_kano_10008.かなり過激な団体らしく、向こうの公安でもマークしてるらしいぞ」
TextENG: ``It's probably best if you go to the location personally.@k@vS05/00/VV_kano_10007. Get some information from the local authorities.@k@vS05/00/VV_kano_10008. They're a fairly radical organization, so the Public Safety Division there should have them marked as well.``

TextJPN: 「わかりました。@k@vS05/13/101300014.現地へ出向します」
TextENG: ``Understood.@k@vS05/13/101300014. I'll head over there.``

TextJPN: 「…奥さん、出産控えてるんだって？@k@vS05/00/VV_kano_10010.　こんなタイミングで申し訳ないけど、協力、頼むよ。@k@vS05/00/VV_kano_10011.時間がかけられないから、人海戦術で総当たりでいくしかないんだ」
TextENG: ``...Your wife, she's almost ready to give birth, isn't she?@k@vS05/00/VV_kano_10010. I apologize for the timing of all this, but I'm counting on your cooperation.@k@vS05/00/VV_kano_10011. We can't take our time with this, so we just have to brute-force it with our boots to the ground.``

TextJPN: 「えぇ、わかってます。@k@vS05/13/101300016.…家内も、自分の都合が私の仕事に障ることを嫌いますから」
TextENG: ``Yeah, I know.@k@vS05/13/101300016. ...My wife hates to interfere with my work with her own circumstances anyways.``

TextJPN: 「すまん、ありがとう。@k@vS05/00/VV_kano_10013.…それから川崎くん佐伯くん、君たちの応援には…、」
TextENG: ``Sorry, and thanks.@k@vS05/00/VV_kano_10013. ...So then, as for Kawasaki-kun and Saeki-kun, to help support your...``

TextJPN: …妻の出産を間近に控えた私としては、出張などしたくはなかった。
TextENG: ...I didn't want to take a business trip when my wife was about to give birth.

TextJPN: 多少忙しくとも、東京にいられれば病院へ飛んで行ける。@k…でも、出張では…難しい。
TextENG: Even if I was a little busy, as long as I was in Tokyo, I could head to the hospital right away.@k ...On assignment, though... that would be difficult.

TextJPN: だが、自分がとても大切な仕事をしていることを理解していたし、私情でわがままが言えるような事態でないことも理解していた。
TextENG: Even so, I knew the work I was doing was important, and fully understood that I was in no position to be so selfish.

TextJPN: この大切な時に側を離れなければならないことを妻に詫びなければ。
TextENG: I'd have to make it up to my wife for having to be away at such an important time.

TextJPN: 妻は、雪絵は笑顔で許すだろう。
TextENG: My wife-- Yukie, would probably forgive me with a smile.

TextJPN: 私の枷になることだけを嫌う性分だから。
TextENG: The only thing she could hate doing would be holding me back.

TextJPN: …それでも敢えて引き止めて欲しいと思うのは、男のエゴだ。
TextENG: ...My male ego, though, at least wished she would have tried to stop me.

TextJPN: すまない、…雪絵。
TextENG: Sorry... Yukie.

TextJPN: お父さんはお前が産まれた時、仕事にかまけてて病院に来なかったんだよって、生まれた子供にずーっと厭味を言ってかまわないから…。
TextENG: I don't mind if you always complain to our child that their father couldn't come to the hospital when they were born because he was too busy with work...

TextJPN: …翌日、私は新幹線で名古屋に向かい、さらにそこからは在来線に乗り換える。
TextENG: ...The next day, I took the bullet train to Nagoya, and from there transferred to the train.

TextJPN: 現地へは陸路で数時間だ。
TextENG: Getting to my destination by land took several hours.

TextJPN: 空路なら、香港あたりまで行けるような時間。@k…雛見沢は決して近くない。
TextENG: If I was travelling by air, in that amount of time I could probably get as far as Hong Kong.@k ...Hinamizawa was by no means close.

TextJPN: 仕事でしか乗ることのないグリーン車は、いつも座席が固く感じた。
TextENG: I never sat in first class except for work, but whenever I did the seats seemed stiff.

TextJPN: 軽く目を閉じ、昨日目を通した資料を思い返す。
TextENG: Closing my eyes, I mentally reviewed the documents I read yesterday.

TextJPN: 調査対象団体、『鬼ヶ淵死守同盟』
TextENG: The group under investigation: the ``Onigafuchi Guardians.``

TextJPN: 雛見沢ダム開発計画に反対する地域の住民団体だ。
TextENG: They were a group of residents opposed to the development proposed under the Hinamizawa Dam Project.

TextJPN: 現地では反対運動がかなり白熱、過激化しているらしい。
TextENG: The local protests were quite heated, and were getting more radicalized.

TextJPN: 新聞で見る限りでも、機動隊との激突による流血事件、ダム工事に対する威力妨害など、枚挙に暇がない。
TextENG: Even limited to what was written in the newspapers, there was bloodshed that occurred during a clash with riot police, interference with the dam construction... too many to count.

TextJPN: 関係機関への陳情や座り込み、直訴なども数知れず。
TextENG: The number of petitions, sit-ins, and direct appeals to the relevant organizations were innumerable.

TextJPN: …その延長には、先日の建設大臣直訴事件がある。
TextENG: ...As an extension of that, there was a direct appeal to the Minister of Construction the other day.

TextJPN: （これがそもそも、今回、この団体を調査することになった@bゆえん.@<所以@>だ）
TextENG: (This was the reason why we were investigating this group in the first place.)

TextJPN: …自分たちの住まう土地が水没するのだから、死に物狂いなのは理解に難しくない。
TextENG: ...The land that they lived on was going to be submerged, so it was no wonder they would go into a frenzy over it.

TextJPN: だからといって、…建設大臣の孫を誘拐して計画の中止を求めるような真似を、こんな連中にできるのか？
TextENG: Even given that, though... could they really be capable of doing something like kidnapping the Minister of Construction's grandson in order to halt the project?

TextJPN: 本音から言えば、甚だ疑問だった。
TextENG: From my take on it, I had serious doubts.

TextJPN: この誘拐劇は極めて高度で、かつ政治的背景が予想される複雑な事件だ。
TextENG: This kidnapping plot was extremely sophisticated, and complicated enough that it was believed there was some political backing.

TextJPN: …反対運動の住民団体風情にできるようなものじゃない。
TextENG: ...This wasn't something that could be pulled off by some group of local protesters.

TextJPN: …だが、室長の言う通りこの調査は、全ての可能性を潰すための一環だ。
TextENG: ...Well, just like the chief said, the plan was to eliminate all possibilities.

TextJPN: この事件は、私が県警の資料室辺りでのんびり調査をしている内に、東京の上級職員たちの手で解明され、解決されるだろう。
TextENG: While I'm in the XX police's reference room taking my time investigating, the higher-ups in Tokyo would probably solve the case.

TextJPN: 私の働きとは関係なく。
TextENG: Without my involvement entirely.

TextJPN: …そう思えば思うほど、妻の出産を控えたこの時期に東京を離れるのが残念でならない。
TextENG: ...Even if that was true, I couldn't regret being away from Tokyo while my wife was ready to give birth.

TextJPN: 仕事さ。@k…仕方ない。
TextENG: This was work.@k ...There was really nothing that I could do.

TextJPN: ピンポンパンポーン…。
TextENG: Ding dong.

TextJPN: 目的地にじき到着することを伝える車内アナウンスに、私は意識をまどろみから戻すのだった。
TextENG: The announcement that we would be arriving at our destination soon snapped me back to wakefulness.

TextJPN: 県警公安部
TextENG: Prefectural Public Safety Division

TextJPN: 「鬼ヶ淵死守同盟ですか」
TextENG: ``The Onigafuchi Guardians?``

TextJPN: 「えぇ、地元ではかなり賑わせているようです」
TextENG: ``Yeah, they've been quite active around here.``

TextJPN: 県警公安では、すでに資料もお茶も用意して、私を待っていてくれた。
TextENG: The Prefectural Public Safety Department already had the documents and a cup of tea ready and waiting for me.

TextJPN: 「早い話がダム反対の住民運動なんですが。@k@vS05/00/104300003.事実上、水没地域の住民全てが決起したと言っていいでしょうね」
TextENG: ``The short of it is they're a group of residents opposed to the dam.@k@vS05/00/104300003. Really, it's probably better to say that every resident living on the land that's going to be submerged is rising to action, though.

TextJPN: 「死守なんて古風な言い方が示す通り、相当の決意と覚悟を持った連中です。@k@vS05/00/104300005.そこら辺の温和な住民団体とは一線を画すと思って頂いた方がいいですね」
TextENG: Like the old saying 'fight to the last,' they're a determined and well-prepared lot.@k@vS05/00/104300005. It'd be nice if they drew the line at just being a moderate residential organization.``

TextJPN: 資料室に用意されていた資料は、決して薄いものではない。
TextENG: The stack of papers they had prepared for me in the document room was by no means thin.

TextJPN: 「発足当初は、ごくごく平均的な住民運動だったんです。@k@vS05/00/104300007.それが、いつだかの流血事件を境に急にヒートアップしまして。@k@vS05/00/104300008.今では暴力主義団体か、それに準じるくらいの過激な勢力に成長したと言えますね」
TextENG: ``At first, they were pretty much your average citizen's initiative,@k@vS05/00/104300007. but ever since that incident with the riot police they've really started to heat up.@k@vS05/00/104300008. Now they've got a violent mentality, on top of growing increasingly radical.``

TextJPN: 暴力主義団体は、自らの思想・イデオロギーを民主主義に則らずに主張しようとする団体を指す。
TextENG: Violent organizations usually indicate ones that enforce their own ideology without regards to the democratic process.

TextJPN: その内訳は、ほとんどが革命思想を持つ団体であることが多い。
TextENG: Breaking that down, many of those organizations held extreme-left revolutionary ideologies.

TextJPN: …それを考えれば、住民運動がそこまで発展する過激さには驚かざるを得ない…。
TextENG: ...Considering that, I couldn't help but be surprised that a citizen's group would end up going this far...

TextJPN: 過激な抵抗をする住民運動も時にはある。
TextENG: Radical citizen's movements happen occasionally.

TextJPN: だが、この団体のそれは、…そんな生易しいものではないらしい。
TextENG: It seemed, however, that this group... was nothing as trifling as that.

TextJPN: …私は、この鬼ヶ淵死守同盟という団体についての認識を少し改める必要があるようだった。
TextENG: ...It seemed that I would have to reconsider exactly what this Onigafuchi Guardians was.

TextJPN: 「……鬼ヶ淵死守同盟が要求、つまりダム計画の撤回を求めるために行いうる活動範囲はどの程度でしょうか？」
TextENG: ``...The Guardians's demand, in other words, the withdrawal of the dam project... how far would they go to have that demand met?``

TextJPN: 大臣の孫の誘拐事件は秘匿されている。
TextENG: The kidnapping of the Minister's grandson was classified.

TextJPN: …それはもちろん、県警の公安にも伝えられていない。
TextENG: ...That meant of course, I couldn't tell the The Prefectural Department about it either.

TextJPN: 「ご存じの通り、先週あった犬飼建設大臣への直訴事件では逮捕者も出ています。@k@vS05/00/104300010.危険性は、十分にありますね」
TextENG: ``As you know, there were arrests after last week's confrontation with Minister Inukai.@k@vS05/00/104300010. They're certainly dangerous enough.``

TextJPN: …主張を通すために、手段を選ばないこともありうるというわけか。
TextENG: ...So they could be expected to use any means necessary to force their demands.

TextJPN: 資料に記載された、鬼ヶ淵死守同盟に関連する犯歴リストを斜め読みする。
TextENG: I skimmed over the list of the criminal records related to the Onigafuchi Guardians recorded in the documents.

TextJPN: …内容はどれも粗暴で、法を遵守しようとする気配は微塵も感じられないものばかりだった。
TextENG: ...The contents were all violent, not giving me the barest hint of a feeling that these people were trying to uphold the law.

TextJPN: 「具体的に、……教えていただけますか？」
TextENG: ``Could you give me any specifics?``

TextJPN: 室長は黄土色のフォルダを開くと、不ぞろいな資料を何枚か漁り、机の上に広げてくれた。
TextENG: The chief opened up a manila envelope, fished out several unorganized sheets and spread them out on the desk.

TextJPN: 「建設現場への襲撃事件がもっとも多かったですね。@k@vS05/00/104300012.初期の頃、電源コードの切断や錠前の鍵穴に石を詰める、投石による事務所の窓ガラス割り等の軽犯罪が頻発していました」
TextENG: ``It seems that raids on the construction site are the most common.@k@vS05/00/104300012. At first, they were committing relatively petty crimes like cutting power cords, jamming locks, and breaking office windows by throwing rocks.``

TextJPN: もちろん本当の初期は、デモ、座り込み、チラシの配布等、賑やかなれど民主的な抵抗運動だった。
TextENG: Of course, what really happened first were things like demonstrations, sit-ins, and distribution of pamphlets; lively but democratic forms of protests.

TextJPN: だが、デモ隊と機動隊が激突して乱闘となり、多数の逮捕者と流血者を出したある事件をきっかけに、鬼ヶ淵死守同盟は文字通り、抵抗運動を鬼の形相に変えていく…。
TextENG: However, then the demonstrators and police clashed, which started a riot, leading to numerous injuries and arrests. It was from then on that the Onigafuchi Guardians, like their name implies, began to take a more demonic form of resistance...

TextJPN: 「襲撃が度重なれば、地元警察による警備強化がなされるのでは？」
TextENG: ``If the raids were frequent, didn't the local police up their patrols?``

TextJPN: 「そりゃ警戒はしたでしょうね。@k@vS05/00/104300014.でもあちらは地元ですから。@k@vS05/00/104300015.闇に乗じて忍び込まれたらお手上げでしょう」
TextENG: ``Well of course they were on full alert,@k@vS05/00/104300014. but they were up against locals, you know?@k@vS05/00/104300015. There wasn't much the police could do if they were sneaking around under the cover of darkness.``

TextJPN: …ダム現場を内包する、雛見沢村地区が丸ごと敵地なのだ。
TextENG: You might as well label the entire map of Hinamizawa Village around the dam construction site 'enemy territory.'

TextJPN: 警察がいくら警備をしたって…、易々と潜り込んでみせるだろう。
TextENG: No matter how alert the police were... the locals would just show them exactly how easy it was to sneak around.

TextJPN: 「警察が警備を固めてからは、むしろ挑発されたように過激化が進みました。@k@vS05/00/104300017.…ほら、このあたりからだいぶヒートアップしてるのがお分かりになります？」
TextENG: ``Actually, it was after the police upped security that the protestors started getting ever more extreme, as though they were being provoked.@k@vS05/00/104300017. ...See here? Can you tell how things started to heat up?``
``...An office set on fire.@k@vS05/13/101300022. ...The destruction of heavy construction equipment.@k@vS05/13/101300023. ...Destruction?@k@vS05/13/101300024. They couldn't have used explosives?``

TextJPN: 「いやまさか。@k@vS05/00/104300019.連中ですね、タンクに角砂糖を放り込むんですよ。@k@vS05/00/104300020.あれやられたら、エンジン焦げ付いちゃいますから」
TextENG: ``No way.@k@vS05/00/104300019. You see, they crammed the gas tanks full of sugar cubes.@k@vS05/00/104300020. If they do that, it fouls the engines.``

TextJPN: …日本でも、終戦直後、進駐軍の車両にそんなことをする輩がいたらしい。
TextENG: Even in Japan, it seemed there had been people doing that to the vehicles of occupying forces right after the war.

TextJPN: …窓ガラスを割るなどというイタズラ紛いに比べると、…極めて暴力的で攻撃的だ。
TextENG: ...Compared to misdemeanors like breaking windows, it was extremely violent and aggressive.

TextJPN: 「…そこまでやられたら、地元警察の面目は丸つぶれですね」
TextENG: ``...After being toyed around with to that extent, the local police have completely lost face.``

TextJPN: 「放火はさすがにですね。@k@vS05/00/104300022.それで地元警察が２４時間態勢の人員を大幅に増員しまして。@k@vS05/00/104300023.それで建設現場への襲撃は一段落したようです」
TextENG: ``The arson was a bit much.@k@vS05/00/104300022. After that, the local police drastically increased the number of personnel they had stationed there around the clock.@k@vS05/00/104300023. The raids on the construction site quieted down a bit after that.``

TextJPN: 室長は一段落という言葉を使ったが、…犯歴リストはそれでやっと真ん中あたりだった。
TextENG: He used the words ``quieted down``... but that was still smack dab in the middle of the list of crimes.

TextJPN: 「で、連中ですね。@k@vS05/00/104300025.現場への直接攻撃が難しくなったと知ったら今度は個人攻撃に切り替えました。@k@vS05/00/104300026.…最初に狙われたのが、工事事務所の現場作業者でした」
TextENG: ``See, after that, they....@k@vS05/00/104300025. After they found that attacking the site had become difficult, they started resorting to personal attacks.@k@vS05/00/104300026. ...The first people targeted were the construction workers.``

TextJPN: そこからは、まさに暗闘。
TextENG: After that, there was silence.

TextJPN: まるで…密林で繰り広げられているゲリラ戦を見るかのようだった…。
TextENG: What was being described to me was a guerilla war fought in the jungle...

TextJPN: 工事従事者への因縁、脅迫、暴力。@k暴言を投げつけ、石すらも投げつけた。
TextENG: Threats and violence against the workers.@k Harsh words and harsher rocks were thrown.

TextJPN: 「……かなりの告訴がされているのに、逮捕者があまり出ていませんね」
TextENG: ``...There's quite a list of accusations here, but there's not a whole lot of convictions.``

TextJPN: 「そりゃそうです。@k@vS05/00/104300028.第一、目撃者なんかいないんですから。@k@vS05/00/104300029.それどころか、現行犯だったにしたって、アリバイがぽんぽんぽんと出来ちゃうんです」
TextENG: ``Of course not.@k@vS05/00/104300028. First of all, there's no witnesses.@k@vS05/00/104300029. On top of that, even if we identify the perpetrators, they have alibis coming out of the woodwork.``
``...?@k@vS05/13/101300028. What do you mean by that?``

TextJPN: 「うー…ん。@k@vS05/00/104300031.…たとえばですね、あなたが雛見沢で歩いていて、@k@vS05/00/104300032.ある男にナイフで刺されたとします。@k@vS05/00/104300033.あなたは相手をよく覚えていて、名前も住所も特定できてるとします」
TextENG: ``Hmmm.@k@vS05/00/104300031. ...Take for example, you're walking around Hinamizawa,@k@vS05/00/104300032. when a certain man stabs you with a knife.@k@vS05/00/104300033. You remember the person clearly, and even know his name and address.

TextJPN: 「ただし、ナイフには指紋がなく、物的証拠だけがない。@k@vS05/00/104300035.…まぁ、ありがちな傷害事件だと思うでしょう？@k@vS05/00/104300036.　でも雛見沢じゃ完全犯罪なんです」
TextENG: However, the knife doesn't have any fingerprints on it, and there's no other physical evidence.@k@vS05/00/104300035. ...Well, you'd think this would be a run-of-the-mill case of assault, wouldn't you?@k@vS05/00/104300036. In Hinamizawa, though, it's a perfect crime.``

TextJPN: 全てが…丸ごと村ぐるみなのだ。
TextENG: Everybody is... the entire village, they're all in on it.

TextJPN: 犯人のはずの男を擁護するため、村中が口裏を合わせてアリバイを用意する。
TextENG: To protect the man who was the perpetrator, they'll get their stories straight and prepare an alibi.

TextJPN: …そのために何らかの証拠の捏造すら行われるだろう。
TextENG: ...To that end, they'll probably even forge some evidence.

TextJPN: 「裁判にもつれ込ます他ないわけですが。@k@vS05/00/104300038.何しろ、物的証拠はない上、犯人を隠匿する証言だけは後から後から増えていく。@k@vS05/00/104300039.…検察も書類送検には二の足を踏むわけです」
TextENG: ``There's nothing they can do but put them on trial.@k@vS05/00/104300038. On top of there not being any material evidence, though, people testify one after another to cover his side of the story.@k@vS05/00/104300039. ...Any prosecutor would hesitate to file charges.

TextJPN: 「殺人ならいざ知れず、投石で額を切った、殴られてアザができた程度だと、仮に犯人を特定できたとしても、嫌疑不十分で送検されないことがほとんどです」
TextENG: I'm not sure about murder, but if it's something like opening a gash on somebody's forehead with a thrown rock, or leaving a bruise after hitting someone, even if you could single out the suspect, there's enough reasonable doubt to not convict.``

TextJPN: どの犯行も、雛見沢の誰かの仕業であることは間違いないが…それを特定できない。
TextENG: Every case is without a doubt perpetrated by someone in Hinamizawa... but they can't identify who.

TextJPN: 仮に誰の仕業だと特定できたとしても、法的に拘束するのに必要な状況証拠が集まらない…。
TextENG: Even if they could figure out who it is, they're unable to obtain enough circumstantial evidence through due process...

TextJPN: 村人たちも、そのあたりを極めて高度に熟知し、陰湿に悪質に…そして執拗に、個人に対する攻撃を続けていった…。
TextENG: The villagers were all extremely well-informed about this, and so the malicious, vicious... and tenacious personal attacks continued...

TextJPN: 「被害者はそれでは納得できないでしょう。@k@vS05/13/101300030.検察審査会に再審請求を出さないのですか？」
TextENG: ``The victims can't have been okay with that, right?@k@vS05/13/101300030. Couldn't they have filed for an appeal?``

TextJPN: 「それはですね、審査員たちが皆、…厄介事に巻き込まれたくないと思っているからですよ。@k@vS05/00/104300042.雛見沢関係のトラブルには、首を突っ込みたがらないんです」
TextENG: ``Well you see, about that, everybody on the Inquest Committee didn't want to get involved with something so troublesome.@k@vS05/00/104300042. They won't stick their noses into anything related to Hinamizawa.``

TextJPN: 検察審査員は、当該地区から無作為に抽出される住民で構成される審査会だ。
TextENG: The Inquest Committee is comprised of a random selection of local residents.

TextJPN: …検察が不起訴とした事件を、再調査するよう差し戻す権限がある。
TextENG: ...In the event the prosecutor fails to get a conviction, they have the power to order a retrial.

TextJPN: 法曹界のエキスパートである検察に、少しでも民意を取り入れるための制度だが…。
TextENG: It's a system designed to assert the will of the people on the actions of expert prosecutors in the legal world...

TextJPN: …地元住民で構成される、という点がここでは裏目に出ていた。
TextENG: ...In this case, however, being composed of local residents has backfired.

TextJPN: 「首を突っ込みたがらない？@k@vS05/13/101300032.　それはなぜです？」
TextENG: ``They don't want to get involved?@k@vS05/13/101300032. Why is that?``

TextJPN: 「……ぅ～ん…。@k@vS05/00/104300044.何て説明すればいいんでしょう…。@k@vS05/00/104300045.恐れられている、って言えばいいのかな…。@k@vS05/00/104300046.…あそこはね、少し特殊なんです」
TextENG: ``...Hmmm...@k@vS05/00/104300044. How do I explain this...@k@vS05/00/104300045. You could say they're afraid...@k@vS05/00/104300046. ...Since it's a little special there.``

TextJPN: 「…特殊？@k@vS05/13/101300034.　なにか、政治的なバックボーンが存在するということですか？」
TextENG: ``...Special?@k@vS05/13/101300034. Are you suggesting they have some sort of political core?``

TextJPN: 「いえ…そういうのとは少し違うというか…。@k@vS05/00/104300048.…まぁその、…怖がられていると思ってください。@k@vS05/00/104300049.このあたりは口では少し説明しにくいんです。@k@vS05/00/104300050.……あぁ、そうだ。わかりやすいのがありました」
TextENG: ``No... it's a little different from that...@k@vS05/00/104300048. ...Well... just think of it as them being afraid.@k@vS05/00/104300049. It's a little hard to explain it just now.@k@vS05/00/104300050. ....Oh, right. There's an easier way.``

TextJPN: 室長はハンカチで額を拭うと、鬼ヶ淵死守同盟構成員リストと書かれたファイルを開き始めた。
TextENG: Wiping his forehead with a handkerchief, he opened a file labeled as a list of members of the Onigafuchi Guardians.

TextJPN: 「鬼ヶ淵死守同盟の勢力にはですね。@k@vS05/00/104300052.…近隣の町々に強い影響力を持つ人間が多々おりまして。@k@vS05/00/104300053.この辺をご覧いただけますか？」
TextENG: ``The power of the Onigafuchi Guardians, you see...@k@vS05/00/104300052. Is the fact that they count many people among their members who are influential in neighboring areas.@k@vS05/00/104300053. Could you take a look at this?``

TextJPN: …見て、少し驚く。
TextENG: ...I looked. What I saw startled me.

TextJPN: 県議に市議、商工会議所の役員たちや、商店会連合会の幹部。
TextENG: Prefectural and municipal assembly members. Staff members of the Chamber of Commerce. An executive of a business association.

TextJPN: …連合町会の幹部やＰＴＡ連絡会関係者など、…地元や周辺地域で強い発言力を持つ者が多く含まれていた。
TextENG: ...An executive of a town council association and a PTA liaison... there were more than a few people with a lot of say both locally and in the neighboring regions.

TextJPN: 「この界隈では、雛見沢のダム反対運動は皆、静観しているのが普通なんです。@k@vS05/00/104300055.…ダムを肯定するような発言をすると、…どこでどう巡って不利益を被るかわからない」
TextENG: ``Around here, you could pretty much expect your actions to be observed by those against the dam project.@k@vS05/00/104300055. ...If you said something in its support... who knows how it'd work out to your disadvantage.

TextJPN: 「何しろ、近隣の町の喉元は、雛見沢出身の人間が抑えていますからね」
TextENG: In any case, every town in this area is being held by the throat by somebody from Hinamizawa.``

TextJPN: 「検察審査員のリストは非公開でしょう？@k@vS05/13/101300036.　報復がされないように何らかの措置が取られているはずでは？」
TextENG: ``The list of Inquisition Committee members is undisclosed, isn't it?@k@vS05/13/101300036. There has to be some measures in place to make sure they'd avoid retribution, no?``

TextJPN: 「…一応、非公開でプライバシーは守られてますがね。@k@vS05/00/104300058.それを管理してるのは、地元の人間なんです」
TextENG: ``...Well, it is undisclosed, so their privacy is assured.@k@vS05/00/104300058. But the person in charge of that is from the Okinomiya Municipal Office. ...In other words, a local.

TextJPN: 「守秘義務があるとは言え、…やはり人間のつながりはわかりませんからね。@k@vS05/00/104300061.雛見沢の人間はそのあたりのつながりが事のほか強固ですから」
TextENG: While you might expect some professional confidentiality... you can't know how everybody is connected.@k@vS05/00/104300061. The people from Hinamizawa have a lot of tight bonds in that regard.``

TextJPN: …地域のしがらみや義理、地縁で編み上げられた情報網は、とても侮れたものではない。
TextENG: ...When you consider the obligations and duties people have to the region, the web of information thereby formed is nothing to scoff at.

TextJPN: 近所の主婦連が、どこのお宅のどこの子が、何年何組で得意教科は何で嫌いな野菜が何かなどに熟知しているなんてことは、よくあることだ。
TextENG: It's not uncommon for housewives in a neighborhood to know which kid from which house is what grade in which school, what subjects they're good at and what vegetables they hate, among other things.

TextJPN: 「…それにほら、…雛見沢と地縁の深い暴力団組織がありましてね。@k@vS05/00/104300063.これが今回の騒動を全面バックアップしてるらしいんです。@k@vS05/00/104300064.こちらが出てくるのが一番、効いてるみたいですね」
TextENG: ``...You see, there's a yakuza organization here with strong ties to Hinamizawa and the surrounding area.@k@vS05/00/104300063. It would seem that they're providing full support in these recent incidents.@k@vS05/00/104300064. They seem to be proving most effective.``

TextJPN: 「暴力団？@k@vS05/13/101300038.　ダムの建設反対で住民と一致？@k@vS05/13/101300039.　…どういう利害が一致するのか読み難いですね」
TextENG: ``Gangsters?@k@vS05/13/101300038. Siding together with the residents opposed to the construction of the dam?@k@vS05/13/101300039. ...It's a little hard to see what their common interest is.``

TextJPN: 「そりゃ難しいことじゃないです。@k@vS05/00/104300066.実はですね、この暴力団の組長がですね、雛見沢村の出身なんです。@k@vS05/00/104300067.村の重鎮のひとりの婿養子に当たりまして」
TextENG: ``It's not that difficult at all.@k@vS05/00/104300066. You see, actually, one of the lieutenants in that gang is originally from Hinamizawa.@k@vS05/00/104300067. He was adopted into a rather influential family in the village.``

TextJPN: ……雛見沢村というのは…どういう村なんだろう。
TextENG: ...Exactly what was this Hinamizawa?

TextJPN: ただのひなびた寒村だと思っていた。
TextENG: I had thought it was some desolate rustic village.

TextJPN: だが、どういうわけか周辺地域に強い影響力を有し、強い連帯感を持ち。@k自分たちの村を守るためなら、どんな暴力的手段も問わない。
TextENG: However, for some reason they exerted a strong influence on the surrounding areas, and had a strong sense of unity.@k They would protect their village by any means necessary, even if that meant resorting to violence.

TextJPN: 室長は、影響力をもつ人物が多いから恐れられている…というような言い方をしたが、@k何となく、村そのものが恐れられているような印象を受ける。
TextENG: The chief had said that they were afraid because there were numerous influential people living there,@k but somehow, I got the feeling that they were afraid of the village itself.

TextJPN: …私が東京で読んだ資料にあるような、単なる反ダムの住民運動とは、明らかに何かが異なっていた。
TextENG: There was something clearly different from what I had read in the documents in Tokyo. This was no simple residential protest against the dam.

TextJPN: なぜか、心に焦燥感が宿る。
TextENG: For some reason, an uneasy feeling began to nestle itself at the back of my mind.

TextJPN: ……私は、…聞き方としては最低の部類に入る方法で。
TextENG: I chose the most basic way to ask my question.

TextJPN: …すなわち、単刀直入に私の知りたいことを切り出した。
TextENG: ...In other words, I directly asked what I wanted to know.

TextJPN: 「………室長。@k@vS05/13/101300041.…これはたとえば、仮の話ですが」
TextENG: ``...Chief.@k@vS05/13/101300041. ...This is just a hypothetical situation, but...``

TextJPN: 「はい？」
「……たとえば、その鬼ヶ淵死守同盟が、@k@vS05/13/101300043.…ダム計画を頓挫させるため、@k@vS05/13/101300044.……たとえば、要人を脅迫するようなことは考えられますか？」
TextENG: ``This... Onigafuchi Guardians.@k@vS05/13/101300043. In order to halt the dam project...@k@vS05/13/101300044. ...Do you think they could, say, threaten somebody important to accomplish that?``

TextJPN: 室長は即答した。
TextENG: The chief replied immediately.

TextJPN: 「ありえるでしょう。@k@vS05/00/104300070.事実、彼らは市役所や県庁、建設省の工事事務所にも押しかけ、恫喝紛いのことをしていますし、@k@vS05/00/104300071.工事関係者の家族が不審者に付け回されたという事件も起こっています」
TextENG: ``It's possible.@k@vS05/00/104300070. Truth be told, they've already gone to municipal and prefectural offices, as well as local offices of the Ministry of Construction and done things that could be construed as intimidation.@k@vS05/00/104300071. Several of the worker's families have also reported that they're being followed around by some suspicious people.``

TextJPN: …それくらいはするだろう。
TextENG: ...Well, that would make sense.

TextJPN: ダム運動と戦うため、工事現場を襲撃し、建設重機を破壊して事務所に放火し。
TextENG: To halt progress on the dam, they raided the construction site, destroying heavy machinery and lighting the construction office on fire.

TextJPN: …工事関係者を襲って、脅迫や暴行を加えることに躊躇がなかった彼らなら、…それくらい平気でやってのけるだろう。
TextENG: If they didn't have any qualms about doing that... threats and violence against people related to the dam would probably be no problem.

TextJPN: ……だが、…そこまでだ。
TextENG: ...But... that was it.

TextJPN: 脅迫や暴行なら誰だって出来る。
TextENG: Even your everyday hoodlum could use threats and violence.

TextJPN: だが、今回の大臣の孫の誘拐は…非常に高度な犯罪だ。
TextENG: However, this time it was the kidnapping of the Minister's grandson... an abnormally high-level crime.

TextJPN: 誘拐そのものの難易度に加え、大臣を交渉開始と同時に屈伏させる手腕など、到底素人とは思えない。
TextENG: Not only was pulling off the kidnapping difficult in the first place, but so was maneuvering to have the minister surrender to their demands immediately. There was no way this was the work of amateurs.

TextJPN: …彼らには、ここまでの犯罪を行なうだけの力があるのか…？
TextENG: ...Did these people have the power to enact this large of a crime...?

TextJPN: 核心はそれ一点だった。
TextENG: That was the heart of the matter.

TextJPN: …鬼ヶ淵死守同盟は、…今回の事件を起こせるだけの組織なのか。
TextENG: Was the Onigafuchi Guardians an organization capable of pulling this off?

TextJPN: …私はそれを聞くため、もう一度。
TextENG: ...In order to ask that question, once again...

TextJPN: …最低の方法で切り出した。
TextENG: ...I chose the most basic method.

TextJPN: 「……たとえば、政府要人の関係者を誘拐して脅迫、…なんてことがありえると思いますか？」
TextENG: ``...Again, hypothetically, do you think... They could kidnap a relative of someone of political importance?``

TextJPN: まさか、そんな大それたことはできませんよ。
TextENG: There's no way they could pull off something that big.

TextJPN: 私が一番期待していた回答だった。
TextENG: That was the answer I most hoped for.

TextJPN: そうであるならば、…私の仕事は半分は終わったも同然。
TextENG: If it was that answer... my work was as good as halfway done.

TextJPN: 妻の出産には立ち会えるかもしれない。@k…そうなるはずだった。
TextENG: I might be able to get back in time for my wife to give birth.@k ...That was how it was supposed to be.

TextJPN: 室長は、躊躇するような仕草を見せもせず、…よどみなく言ってのけた。
TextENG: The chief, without a hint of hesitation, replied:

TextJPN: 「やるかもしれません。@k@vS05/00/104300073.…底の知れない連中ですから」
TextENG: ``They just might.@k@vS05/00/104300073. There's no telling how far they'd go.``

TextJPN: …ごめん、雪絵。
TextENG: ...Sorry, Yukie.

TextJPN: ……やはり私の仕事は、簡単には終わらなさそうだった。
TextENG: ...It seemed like my work wouldn't end so simply after all.

TextJPN: 「…お、赤坂くんか。@k@vS05/00/104200034.ご苦労さん。@k@vS05/00/104200035.担当地域での情報収集はどうですか」
TextENG: ``...Oh, Akasaka-kun.@k@vS05/00/104200034. Good work.@k@vS05/00/104200035. How's the information gathering at your assigned region?``

TextJPN: 「順調です。@k@vS05/13/101300047.これから現地警察の公安と接触できることになりましたので、現地へ向かう予定です。@k@vS05/13/101300048.東京の調査の方はどうですか？」
TextENG: ``It's coming along.@k@vS05/13/101300047. It seems I'll be able to meet with their local Public Safety Department, so I'm planning on heading out that way.@k@vS05/13/101300048. How's the investigation in Tokyo going?``

TextJPN: 「他の職員も順調に調査を進めているよ。@k@vS05/00/104200037.でも調べる団体が星の数だからね。@k@vS05/00/104200038.そんなに悠長に時間もかけられないし」
TextENG: ``The others are progressing along,@k@vS05/00/104200037. but the number of groups we have to investigate are countless.@k@vS05/00/104200038. Time isn't really a luxury here.``

TextJPN: …進展は今のところなし。
TextENG: ...There were no new developments at this time.

TextJPN: どんなに鬼ヶ淵死守同盟が疑わしくたって、東京で解決すれば私の仕事は終わる。@k…そういう甘えは通用しないようだった。
TextENG: No matter how suspicious the Onigafuchi Guardians was, if they solved the case in Tokyo, my job was done.@k ...It looked like my wishful thinking wouldn't come to pass.

TextJPN: 受話器を置き、窓から見える異郷のビルの谷間に視線を泳がせた…。
TextENG: Hanging up the phone, I let my gaze drift outside the window to the valley of unfamiliar buildings...

TextJPN: 「赤坂さん。@k@vS05/00/104300075.今、お貸しできる車が戻ってきました。@k@vS05/00/104300076.ご案内しますのでこちらへどうぞ」
TextENG: ``Akasaka-san.@k@vS05/00/104300075. A car you can borrow just returned.@k@vS05/00/104300076. I'll take you to it, so follow me.``

TextJPN: 「あ、すみません」
TextENG: ``Ah, thank you.``

TextJPN: エレベーターで地下駐車場に案内され、いい具合にくたびれた乗用車を用意してもらった。
TextENG: He showed me the elevator to the underground parking lot where a battered sedan was waiting for me.

TextJPN: ハンドルがやや左に泳ぐクセが少し気になったが、しばらくの間の私の足になるには充分だった。
TextENG: That the steering wheel kept drifting to the left was a little concerning, but it would be enough to get me around for a while.

TextJPN: 向かうは、鹿骨市。
TextENG: My destination was Shishibone City.

TextJPN: …鬼ヶ淵死守同盟の勢力圏。@kその最前線を預かる、興宮警察署だった。
TextENG: ...An area under the control of the Onigafuchi Guardians.@k The Okinomiya Police Station was right on the front lines.
